No, the technique of using a seemingly innocuous object to send a threatening message or to signify a sinister plot is not used in "The Sign of Four." In that story, the mystery revolves around a valuable treasure, a missing army officer, and a mysterious tattoo on the wrist of a dead man.

In "The Sign of Four," Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson are hired by a young woman named Mary Morstan to investigate the disappearance of her father, who was a British Army officer stationed in India. The case leads them to a complex web of intrigue involving stolen treasure, secret pacts, and a band of ruthless criminals.

While the story does involve several clever plot twists and surprises, the technique of using an innocuous object as a symbol or threat is not a major element of the plot. Instead, the focus is on the intricate mystery and the interplay between the various characters, including Holmes, Watson, and the enigmatic Mary Morstan.

Overall, "The Sign of Four" is a classic example of a detective story, with a complex and intriguing plot, a colorful cast of characters, and plenty of suspense and intrigue.
